'''Caroline Paul''' (born July 29, 1963 in [[New York City]]) is an [[United States|American]] [[writer]] of [[fiction]] and [[nonfiction]]. She was raised in Connecticut (her father was an investment banker, her mother a social worker), and educated in [[journalism]] and [[documentary film]] at [[Stanford University]].<ref name="stanford">[http://www.stanfordalumni.org/news/magazine/1998/novdec/articles/firefighter.html Stanford University alumnus biography]</ref> She worked as a journalist at Berkeley [[public radio]] station [[KPFA]] before (in 1988) joining the [[San Francisco Fire Department]], as one of the first women hired by the department.<ref name="stanford"/> She worked most of her career on Rescue 2, where she and her crew were responsible for search and rescue in fires. Rescue 2 members were also trained and sent on scuba dive searches, rope and rappelling rescues, surf rescues, confined space rescues, all hazardous material calls, and the most severe train and car wrecks.
Her first book was the nonfiction [[memoir]] ''Fighting Fire'', published in 1998. Her second, the 2006 [[historical novel]] ''East Wind, Rain'' is based on the [[Niihau Incident]], a historical event in which a Japanese pilot crash-landed on the private Hawaiian island of [[Niihau]], after the [[attack on Pearl Harbor]]. She is a member of the San Francisco Writers' Grotto, a workspace co-operative that also includes [[Po Bronson]], [[Tom Barbash]], [[Stephen Elliott (author)|Stephen Elliott]], [[Peter Orner]], [[ZZ Packer]], [[Jason Roberts (author)|Jason Roberts]], [[Ethan Watters]] and [[B. Ruby Rich]].<ref name="grotto">[http://www.sfgrotto.org/inhabitants.html "Inhabitants"], SF Writer's Grotto website</ref>
Her [[identical twins|identical twin]] sister is ''[[Baywatch]]'' actress [[Alexandra Paul]].<ref name="alexandrapaulwebsite">[http://www.alexandrapaul.com/biography.htm "Alexandra Paul: biography"], Alexandra Paul's website</ref> Together, the two sisters occupied a single slot on ''[[People Magazine]]'s'' list of "50 Most Beautiful People" for 1997.{{Fact|date=April 2009}} Her younger brother Jonathan Paul is a militant [[animal rights activist]]; he is currently serving a four year sentence in federal prison for the 1997 arson of a slaughterhouse in Redmond, Oregon.<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/2007/aug/02/nation/na-arson2 "Environmentalist is sentenced to 4 years for arson"], ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', October 27 2007</ref><ref>[http://www.alexandrapaul.com/corner/jonathan.htm "My brother is in prison. He is my hero..."], Alexandra Paul's website statement about her brother</ref>
Caroline flies [[ultralight]]s and [[paraglider]]s. An accomplished athlete, she has competed on the U.S. National [[Luge]] Team in trials for the [[Olympics]].<ref name="ownbio">[http://www.carolinepaul.com/biography.htm "Biography"], Caroline Paul's website</ref>
